Award.AwardTitle: Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution - Oceanographic Instrumentation (Moored Instrumentation to Support Present and Future Field Programs)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funding is requested for the acquisition of new sensors in support of POOL. The Physical Oceanography Observing Laboratory (POOL) of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution is a virtual facility that maintains and provides moored instrumentation to U.S. investigators conducting research supported by the National Science Foundation and other national agencies. Component laboratory groups construct the mooring elements and prepare the sensors, go to sea to deploy and recover moorings and, if requested by the principal investigator, extract and process the data from the moored instrumentation and make them ready for scientific analysis. Nearly 5 years ago now, the POOL instrumentation was significantly renewed through a Major Research Instrumentation grant. Nevertheless, the present inventory of POOL instrumentation is fully committed to current, ongoing projects, greatly restricting the ability to support
new initiatives in the near future. Moreover, overlapping deployments now scheduled will
result in a shortfall in some requested instruments. Acquisition of selected new moored sensors
is requested here to address this shortfall and facilitate future field work. Instrumentation requested includes:
1) Nortek Aquadopp current meters $128,160
2) Seabird SBE 37SM MicroCats $116,920
3) MMP upgrade/overhaul/modifications $103,425
4) EdgeTech 8242XS acoustic releases $133,200
5) Seabird SBE 37SM MicroCats $116,920
6) MMP upgrade/overhaul/modifications $103,425
$702,050
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The WHOI Field Instrumentation and Experiment Implementation Team (FIXIT) laboratory supports a suite of oceanographic moored sensors on a shared-use basis and assists investigators with mooring deployment/recovery operations.  The major goals of the current project are to replace old, obsolete, and unreliable instruments in the FIXIT inventory such as the Vector Averaging Current Meter (VACM), 1st generation sensor suites of McLane Moored Profilers (MMP), and old Seabird Microcats.  An additional goal is to increase the inventory of the most frequently used instruments that are requested for NSF funded projects, giving us the ability to assure P.I.s that if their proposal is awarded, there will be instruments available, while continuing to provide instruments for currently funded NSF projects. During the 4 year period of the Moored Instrument Support grant, we have been able to accomplish the main goals of upgrading and replacing an aging inventory of instruments and equipment that are most frequently requested, and used by the oceanographic community. With the initial installment of funds, we were able to purchase Seabird Microcat ctd's , Nortek Aquadopp current meters, and Edgetech acoustic releases to cover our immediate needs at that time. As we moved into the following years we were able to get a better sense of what the future needs of the P.I.'s who are supported by FIXIT. This helped us anticipate how to best use the remaining funds based on the instrumentation requests we were receiving. Because of the uncertainty of proposals being awarded, consideration was given to those projects that were likely to receive funding and the instruments that would most benefit those projects. We determined that the remaining funds would be best used by purchasing more Seabird Microcat ctd's, Edgetech acoustic releases, and upgrading the main controller electronics on MMP's (McLane Moored Profiler). In total we were able to add significant numbers to our usable inventory to the benefit of existing funded projects at the time this grant was awarded, but also benefitting projects that have recently been awarded that will be continuing to field mooring array projects over the next few years. In total we were able to purchase 47 Seabird Microcats, 17 Edgetech acoustic releases, 10 Nortek Aquadopp current meters, and 14 MMP/CF2 controller upgrades, all of which have been added to the FIXIT instrument pool inventory. We were also able to purchase new Edgetech acoustic communication deck units that are frequently loaned out for field programs that are using compatible acoustic releases.The FIXIT lab has been able to routinely satisfy the instrument and equipment requests of many existing NSF funded projects, as well as ensure the instrument availability of projects that are in the proposal stage, as a result of the funds that were provided through the Moored Instrument Support grant.
